segments.en: Numbered Discourses 3
4. Messengers of the Gods
36. Messengers of the Gods
“There are, mendicants, these three messengers of the gods.
What three?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco kāyena duccaritaṃ carati, vācāya duccaritaṃ carati, manasā duccaritaṃ carati.
segments.en: Firstly, someone does bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.

segments.pli: So kāyena duccaritaṃ caritvā, vācāya duccaritaṃ caritvā, manasā duccaritaṃ caritvā kāyassa bhedā paraṃ maraṇā apāyaṃ duggatiṃ vinipātaṃ nirayaṃ upapajjati.
segments.en: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.

segments.pli: Tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā nānābāhāsu gahetvā yamassa rañño dassenti:
segments.en: Then the wardens of hell take them by the arms and present them to King Yama, saying:

segments.pli: ‘ayaṃ, deva, puriso amatteyyo apetteyyo asāmañño abrahmañño, na kule jeṭṭhāpacāyī.
segments.en: ‘Your Majesty, this person did not pay due respect to their mother and father, ascetics and brahmins, or honor the elders in the family.
May Your Majesty punish them!’

segments.pli: Tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, yamo rājā paṭhamaṃ devadūtaṃ samanuyuñjati samanugāhati samanubhāsati:
segments.en: Then King Yama pursues, presses, and grills them about the first messenger of the gods:

segments.pli: ‘ambho, purisa, na tvaṃ addasa manussesu paṭhamaṃ devadūtaṃ pātubhūtan’ti?
segments.en: ‘Mister, did you not see the first messenger of the gods that appeared among human beings?’
They say,
‘I saw nothing, sir.’
Then King Yama says,

segments.pli: ‘ambho purisa, na tvaṃ addasa manussesu itthiṃ vā purisaṃ vā āsītikaṃ vā nāvutikaṃ vā vassasatikaṃ vā jātiyā jiṇṇaṃ gopānasivaṅkaṃ bhoggaṃ daṇḍaparāyaṇaṃ pavedhamānaṃ gacchantaṃ āturaṃ gatayobbanaṃ khaṇḍadantaṃ palitakesaṃ vilūnaṃ khallitasiraṃ valitaṃ tilakāhatagattan’ti?
segments.en: ‘Mister, did you not see among human beings an elderly woman or a man—eighty, ninety, or a hundred years old—bent double, crooked, leaning on a staff, trembling as they walk, ailing, past their prime, with teeth broken, hair grey and scanty or bald, skin wrinkled, and limbs blotchy?’
They say,
‘I saw that, sir.’
Then King Yama says,

segments.pli: ‘ambho, purisa, tassa te viññussa sato mahallakassa na etadahosi—
segments.en: ‘Mister, did it not occur to you—being sensible and mature—

segments.pli: ahampi khomhi jarādhammo jaraṃ anatīto, handāhaṃ kalyāṇaṃ karomi, kāyena vācāya manasā’ti?
segments.en: “I, too, am liable to grow old. I’m not exempt from old age. I’d better do good by way of body, speech, and mind”?’
They say,
‘I couldn’t, sir. I was negligent.’
Then King Yama says,

segments.pli: ‘ambho, purisa, pamādatāya na kalyāṇamakāsi kāyena vācāya manasā.
segments.en: ‘Mister, because you were negligent, you didn’t do good by way of body, speech, and mind.

segments.pli: Taggha tvaṃ, ambho purisa, tathā karissanti yathā taṃ pamattaṃ.
segments.en: Indeed, they’ll definitely punish you to fit your negligence.

segments.pli: Taṃ kho pana te etaṃ pāpakammaṃ neva mātarā kataṃ, na pitarā kataṃ, na bhātarā kataṃ, na bhaginiyā kataṃ, na mittāmaccehi kataṃ, na ñātisālohitehi kataṃ, na devatāhi kataṃ, na samaṇabrāhmaṇehi kataṃ;
segments.en: That bad deed wasn’t done by your mother, father, brother, or sister. It wasn’t done by friends and colleagues, by relatives and kin, by the deities, or by ascetics and brahmins.

segments.pli: atha kho tayāvetaṃ pāpakammaṃ kataṃ, tvaññevetassa vipākaṃ paṭisaṃvedissasī’ti. (1)
segments.en: That bad deed was done by you alone, and you alone will experience the result.’

segments.pli: Tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, yamo rājā paṭhamaṃ devadūtaṃ samanuyuñjitvā samanugāhitvā samanubhāsitvā, dutiyaṃ devadūtaṃ samanuyuñjati samanugāhati samanubhāsati:
segments.en: Then King Yama grills them about the second messenger of the gods:

segments.pli: ‘ambho purisa, na tvaṃ addasa manussesu dutiyaṃ devadūtaṃ pātubhūtan’ti?
segments.en: ‘Mister, did you not see the second messenger of the gods that appeared among human beings?’
They say,
‘I saw nothing, sir.’
Then King Yama says,

segments.pli: ‘ambho purisa, na tvaṃ addasa manussesu itthiṃ vā purisaṃ vā ābādhikaṃ dukkhitaṃ bāḷhagilānaṃ, sake muttakarīse palipannaṃ semānaṃ, aññehi vuṭṭhāpiyamānaṃ, aññehi saṃvesiyamānan’ti?
segments.en: ‘Mister, did you not see among human beings a woman or a man, sick, suffering, gravely ill, collapsed in their own urine and feces, being picked up by some and put down by others?’
They say,
‘I saw that, sir.’
Then King Yama says,

segments.pli: ‘ambho purisa, tassa te viññussa sato mahallakassa na etadahosi:
segments.en: ‘Mister, did it not occur to you—being sensible and mature—

segments.pli: “ahampi khomhi byādhidhammo byādhiṃ anatīto, handāhaṃ kalyāṇaṃ karomi kāyena vācāya manasā”’ti?
segments.en: “I, too, am liable to become sick. I’m not exempt from sickness. I’d better do good by way of body, speech, and mind”?’
They say,
‘I couldn’t, sir. I was negligent.’
Then King Yama says,

segments.pli: ‘ambho purisa, pamādatāya na kalyāṇamakāsi kāyena vācāya manasā.
segments.en: ‘Mister, because you were negligent, you didn’t do good by way of body, speech, and mind.

segments.pli: Taggha tvaṃ, ambho purisa, tathā karissanti yathā taṃ pamattaṃ.
segments.en: Well, they’ll definitely punish you to fit your negligence.

segments.pli: Taṃ kho pana te etaṃ pāpakammaṃ neva mātarā kataṃ, na pitarā kataṃ, na bhātarā kataṃ, na bhaginiyā kataṃ, na mittāmaccehi kataṃ, na ñātisālohitehi kataṃ, na devatāhi kataṃ, na samaṇabrāhmaṇehi kataṃ;
segments.en: That bad deed wasn’t done by your mother, father, brother, or sister. It wasn’t done by friends and colleagues, by relatives and kin, by the deities, or by ascetics and brahmins.

segments.pli: atha kho tayāvetaṃ pāpakammaṃ kataṃ. Tvaññevetassa vipākaṃ paṭisaṃvedissasī’ti. (2)
segments.en: That bad deed was done by you alone, and you alone will experience the result.’

segments.pli: Tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, yamo rājā dutiyaṃ devadūtaṃ samanuyuñjitvā samanugāhitvā samanubhāsitvā, tatiyaṃ devadūtaṃ samanuyuñjati samanugāhati samanubhāsati:
segments.en: Then King Yama grills them about the third messenger of the gods:

segments.pli: ‘ambho purisa, na tvaṃ addasa manussesu tatiyaṃ devadūtaṃ pātubhūtan’ti?
segments.en: ‘Mister, did you not see the third messenger of the gods that appeared among human beings?’
They say,
‘I saw nothing, sir.’
Then King Yama says,

segments.pli: ‘ambho purisa, na tvaṃ addasa manussesu itthiṃ vā purisaṃ vā ekāhamataṃ vā dvīhamataṃ vā tīhamataṃ vā uddhumātakaṃ vinīlakaṃ vipubbakajātan’ti?
segments.en: ‘Mister, did you not see among human beings a woman or a man, dead for one, two, or three days, bloated, livid, and festering?’
They say,
‘I saw that, sir.’
Then King Yama says,

segments.pli: ‘ambho purisa, tassa te viññussa sato mahallakassa na etadahosi—
segments.en: ‘Mister, did it not occur to you—being sensible and mature—

segments.pli: ahampi khomhi maraṇadhammo maraṇaṃ anatīto, handāhaṃ kalyāṇaṃ karomi kāyena vācāya manasā’ti?
segments.en: “I, too, am liable to die. I’m not exempt from death. I’d better do good by way of body, speech, and mind”?’
They say,
‘I couldn’t, sir. I was negligent.’
Then King Yama says,

segments.pli: ‘ambho purisa, pamādatāya na kalyāṇamakāsi kāyena vācāya manasā.
segments.en: ‘Mister, because you were negligent, you didn’t do good by way of body, speech, and mind.

segments.pli: Taggha tvaṃ, ambho purisa, tathā karissanti yathā taṃ pamattaṃ.
segments.en: Well, they’ll definitely punish you to fit your negligence.

segments.pli: Taṃ kho pana te etaṃ pāpakammaṃ neva mātarā kataṃ, na pitarā kataṃ, na bhātarā kataṃ, na bhaginiyā kataṃ, na mittāmaccehi kataṃ, na ñātisālohitehi kataṃ, na devatāhi kataṃ, na samaṇabrāhmaṇehi kataṃ;
segments.en: That bad deed wasn’t done by your mother, father, brother, or sister. It wasn’t done by friends and colleagues, by relatives and kin, by the deities, or by ascetics and brahmins.

segments.pli: atha kho tayāvetaṃ pāpakammaṃ kataṃ. Tvaññevetassa vipākaṃ paṭisaṃvedissasī’”ti. (3)
segments.en: That bad deed was done by you alone, and you alone will experience the result.’

segments.pli: Tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, yamo rājā tatiyaṃ devadūtaṃ samanuyuñjitvā samanugāhitvā samanubhāsitvā tuṇhī hoti.
segments.en: Then, after grilling them about the third messenger of the gods, King Yama falls silent.

segments.pli: Tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā pañcavidhabandhanaṃ nāma kāraṇaṃ karonti.
segments.en: Then the wardens of hell punish them with the five-fold crucifixion.

segments.pli: Tattaṃ ayokhilaṃ hatthe gamenti. Tattaṃ ayokhilaṃ dutiyasmiṃ hatthe gamenti. Tattaṃ ayokhilaṃ pāde gamenti. Tattaṃ ayokhilaṃ dutiyasmiṃ pāde gamenti. Tattaṃ ayokhilaṃ majjhe urasmiṃ gamenti.
segments.en: They drive red-hot stakes through the hands and feet, and another in the middle of the chest.

segments.pli: So tattha dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vediyati, na ca tāva kālaṃ karoti yāva na taṃ pāpakammaṃ byantīhoti.
segments.en: And there they feel painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.

segments.pli: Tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā saṃvesetvā kudhārīhi tacchanti.
segments.en: Then the wardens of hell thrown them down and hack them with axes. …

segments.pli: So tattha dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vediyati, na ca tāva kālaṃ karoti yāva na taṃ pāpakammaṃ byantīhoti.
Tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā uddhampādaṃ adhosiraṃ gahetvā vāsīhi tacchanti … pe …
segments.en: They hang them upside-down and hack them with hatchets. …

segments.pli: tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā rathe yojetvā ādittāya bhūmiyā sampajjalitāya sajotibhūtāya sārentipi paccāsārentipi … pe …
segments.en: They harness them to a chariot, and drive them back and forth across burning ground, blazing and glowing. …

segments.pli: tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā mahantaṃ aṅgārapabbataṃ ādittaṃ sampajjalitaṃ sajotibhūtaṃ āropentipi oropentipi … pe …
segments.en: They make them climb up and down a huge mountain of burning coals, blazing and glowing. …

segments.pli: tamenaṃ, bhikkhave, nirayapālā uddhampādaṃ adhosiraṃ gahetvā tattāya lohakumbhiyā pakkhipanti, ādittāya sampajjalitāya sajotibhūtāya. ()
segments.en: Then the wardens of hell turn them upside down and throw them in a red-hot copper pot, burning, blazing, and glowing.

segments.pli: So tattha pheṇuddehakaṃ paccamāno sakimpi uddhaṃ gacchati, sakimpi adho gacchati, sakimpi tiriyaṃ gacchati.
segments.en: There they’re seared in boiling scum, and they’re swept up and down and round and round.

segments.pli: So tattha dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vediyati, na ca tāva kālaṃ karoti yāva na taṃ pāpakammaṃ byantīhoti.
segments.en: And there they feel painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.
Then the wardens of hell toss them into the Great Hell.
Now, about that Great Hell:
‘Four are its corners, four its doors,
divided into measured parts.
Surrounded by an iron wall,
of iron is its roof.
The ground is even made of iron,
it burns with fierce fire.
The heat forever radiates
a hundred leagues around.’
Once upon a time, King Yama thought,

segments.pli: ‘ye kira, bho, loke pāpakāni kammāni karonti te evarūpā vividhā kammakāraṇā karīyanti.
segments.en: ‘Those who do such bad deeds in the world receive these many different punishments.

segments.pli: Aho vatāhaṃ manussattaṃ labheyyaṃ, tathāgato ca loke uppajjeyya arahaṃ sammāsambuddho, tañcāhaṃ bhagavantaṃ payirupāseyyaṃ.
segments.en: Oh, I hope I may be reborn as a human being! And that a Realized One—a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha—arises in the world! And that I may pay homage to the Buddha!

segments.pli: So ca me bhagavā dhammaṃ deseyya, tassa cāhaṃ bhagavato dhammaṃ ājāneyyan’ti.
segments.en: Then the Buddha can teach me Dhamma, so that I may understand his teaching.’

segments.pli: Taṃ kho panāhaṃ, bhikkhave, na aññassa samaṇassa vā brāhmaṇassa vā sutvā evaṃ vadāmi, api ca kho, bhikkhave, yadeva me sāmaṃ ñātaṃ sāmaṃ diṭṭhaṃ sāmaṃ viditaṃ tadevāhaṃ vadāmīti.
segments.en: Now, I don’t say this because I’ve heard it from some other ascetic or brahmin. I only say it because I’ve known, seen, and realized it for myself.
Those people who are negligent,
when warned by the gods’ messengers:
a long time they sorrow,
when they go to that wretched place.
But those good and peaceful people,
when warned by the god’s messengers,
never neglect
the teaching of the noble ones.
Seeing the peril in grasping,
the origin of birth and death,
they’re freed by not grasping,
with the ending of birth and death.
Happy, they’ve come to a safe place,
extinguished in this very life.
They’ve gone beyond all threats and perils,
and risen above all suffering.”

sections.title: “There are, mendicants, these three messengers of the gods.…

suttaplex.blurb: The god of death questions us, but we are punished by our own deeds.
